thread.title: Kentucky’s next sensation on NCAA ride as a practice menace
thread.title_full: Kentucky’s next sensation on NCAA ride as a practice menace | New York Post

author: Zach Braziller
title: Kentucky’s next sensation on NCAA ride as a practice menace
text:
MEMPHIS, Tenn. — As Kentucky’s stars were surrounded by members of the media Thursday, Hamidou Diallo sat at his locker, taking it all in.
It was symbolic of the Queens native’s past two months, watching and learning as his fellow Wildcats battled on the court, winning the SEC regular season and postseason crown, then moving through the first weekend of the NCAA Tournament.
Diallo, a five-star recruit known for his athletic ability and leaping prowess, made the unorthodox move of enrolling in school in January — choosing Kentucky over UConn, Arizona and Syracuse — but opting not to play.
“It was all about being prepared and not rushing things,” Diallo told The Post, before No. 2 Kentucky met third-seeded UCLA in a South Region semifinal at FedExForum in Memphis Friday night. “Just coming in, getting used to the system, getting used to [coach John Calipari], getting used to all the coaches, and getting used to these guys.”
There have been times the 6-foot-6 shooting guard has second-guessed that decision, feeling he could help Kentucky on the floor. As his teammates talked about the huge game against UCLA, Diallo discussed why he wasn’t on the floor. It grated on him.
“For any competitor and basketball player, I feel like it’s hard to be on the bench. This is the most I’ve ever sat on the bench,” he said. “Any competitor would feel like they can go out there and give it their all, lead these guys to a victory. Being with these guys, not being able to help them on the court, it’s tough. But it’s part of the plan.”
Malik Monk Getty Images Diallo’s early enrollment has been a positive, too. He has faced elite competition daily in practice, going against projected top-10 NBA draft picks De’Aaron Fox and Malik Monk, and they have gotten to face him, too, raising their games as well.
“We’re glad we got him here, because he’s been helping us in practice,” Monk recently told reporters. “He’s going to be a great player. He’s going to be a competitor. That’s what he does. He plays physical with us. He’s not going to give us any breaks. He’s like 6-6. Great length. Great defender. We’re just happy to have him.”
Diallo graduated from Putnam Science Academy (Conn.) last year, making him eligible for this June’s draft. But Diallo repeatedly has said he wanted to play college basketball. That remains the plan. He will be part of another blockbuster Kentucky team next year, barring a change of heart, a group of elite freshmen that includes five-star prospects and McDonald’s All-Americans Nick Richards, Quade Green, Jarred Vanderbilt and P.J. Washington.
Diallo has a head start on them. He already has learned Kentucky’s system, already gotten a taste of the pressure and hype that comes with being a Wildcat, already has seen what Calipari expects from his stars. He has gained seven pounds of muscle and feels like his jumpshot — the biggest knock of his game — has improved.
“I think it made me a better player already. I’m just a much better player than before I came into these doors,” Diallo said. “Much faster, much stronger. My development has been great.
“I think it was just a great decision I made. I can’t wait to get on the court next year.”
